### Version

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/skeith69/marketplace](https://github.com/skeith69/marketplace)

### Steps to reproduce
create admins, roles and permissions.
then click View Admins Link and Assign Roles to any admin created any button (Unassign or Assign).

### What is expected?
The BS4 progress bar should appear when the button Unassigned or Assign is clicked because the value of v-show is changed to true.

### What is actually happening?
role object { name: 'admin', display_ame: 'Admin', 'description: 'Description', isRequesting: false. isAssigned: false }

when I changed the isRequesting to true. the BS4 progress bar should appear but it does not. the UI is not updating.

(adding a space then removing the space in role object name attribute)

---
This is a Laravel project with VueJS as the Front-end.

do the following command for installation of packages.
composer install
npm install

after installation do the following commands

php artisan migrate:fresh
php artisan passport:install

the file is located in /resources/assets/js/admins/views/admins/AssignRole.vue
please comment out line

129 => this.roles[index].display_name = this.roles[index].display_name   ' ';
and
131 => this.roles[index].display_name.trim();

Issues.Title: Transition behavior is different when an uncalled done is provided in hook method
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[http://jsbin.com/wotazalama/1/edit?html,css,js,output](http://jsbin.com/wotazalama/1/edit?html,css,js,output)

### Steps to reproduce
In the demo link, click toggle to show and hide element

### What is expected?
The two boxes are configured with `<transition>`, only differs in enter and leave hook.   
One is called with `enter(el){...}` and `leave(el){ ... }` .  
The other one is called with `enter(el, done){...}` and `leave(el, done){ .... }.   
Both function do the same thing and the done callback is not called.   
It is expected that the two boxes enter and leave the same way.

### What is actually happening?
Box hooked with `enter(el, done){...}` and `leave(el, done){...}` do transition properly.  
Box hooked with `enter(el){...}` and `leave(el){...}` do not have leave transition.

---
This is a re-submit of #8275 , I have messed up that demo. This one should properly demo the case.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: render issue when transition-group child is a component that loads asynchronously
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[http://www.google.com](http://www.google.com)

### Steps to reproduce
I don't have time to create a minim repro at the moment so feel free to close this report if you feel it's user error, or a known issue, but here is some pseudo-code:

--- in the parent
```
<transition-group>
<custom-component v-for="a in array"/>
</transition-group>
```
--- in the custom component 

```
<template>
<subsubcomponent/>
</template>

components: {
    subsubcomponent: () =>
    new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(() => resolve(import("subsubcomponent.vue")),5000))
}
```
--- 

I'm adding the artificial loading delay to make the issue reproducible. With no setTimeout() it happens sporadically depending on load times. If I remove the `<transition-group>` then the rendering never fails.

The error message is:
```
[Vue warn]: Error in updated hook: "TypeError: Cannot read property 'cloneNode' of undefined"

found in

---> <TransitionGroup>
       <CCoachList> at src\components\cCoachList.vue
         <CCoachDirectory> at src\components\pages\cCoachDirectory.vue
```


### What is expected?
transition-group loads components as they become available

### What is actually happening?
if components take too long to load, the first item in the in the group displays correctly, the others fail

Issues.Title: Set object is not reactive
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/86us8zxz/2/](https://jsfiddle.net/86us8zxz/2/)

### Steps to reproduce
Attach a `new Set()` object to the `data` attribute of a component and modify it by using the set's methods (add, delete, etc).

### What is expected?
Changes in the set would reflect in the rendered HTML, just like they do for arrays.

### What is actually happening?
Nothing - the change of the set isn't picked up by Vue, making this property not reactive. This is unusual because mutations of an array works as expected (see link).

### Additional notes
[https://jsfiddle.net/86us8zxz/3/](https://jsfiddle.net/86us8zxz/3/) shows that the change in the set seems to be detected (unless the reactive system of Vue works different to my understanding) as the view updates when the set is converted to an array.


<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Set object is not reactive" (#8272)

Issues.Title: Model implementation
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Hi everybody,

I would like to submit an idea in order to continue make vuejs an awesome tool.
I'm from the back end world and I started a project with vuejs some months ago to discover the javascript ecosystem. First, I was realy enthusiastic about vue and all its features but I found that something was missing: a way to declare a model/entity to represent a data object.

I don't know what you are thinking about a such feature but I think it could be a good option to add an other library (like the router, or even the cli) to guide vue developers with data manipulations and in the same way, promote best practices in this field.

Thank you to consider my proposition.

### What does the proposed API look like?
My proposition is to integrate a library to bring the M from MVC to the V from Vue of course without dealing with persistence. Or at least to guide developers to deal with this implementation. The data attribute of a Vue component could be composed of multiple models instance, because a component is not a data object itself and it shouldn't be.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112](https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112)

### Steps to reproduce
Look at the codepen snippet.

It contains **isObjectEqual(a, b)** implementation from *vue-router/src/util/route.js* and an example of it's unexpected behaviour.

Console output represents the issue.

### What is expected?
In the codepen **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is used on two objects: 

```a: { foo: true, bar: undefined } ```

```b: { foo: true, baz: 'qux' } ```

What is expected: 
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is expected to return false since **Object b** has 'baz' property with 'qux' value and **Object a**  doesn't have such property at all.

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** is expected to return false for the same reason.

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result should be equal to **isObjectEqual (b, a)** result.

### What is actually happening?
What is happening:
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** returns true (unexpected).

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** returns false (expected).  

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result is not equal to **isObjectEqual(b, a)** result  (unexpected).

Same thing will happen with any **Object a** and **Object b** if conditions below are met:

- **Object a** and **Object b** have the same amount of properties.

- **Object b** must have same properties with same values that are present in **Object a** with values different from undefined.


---
Issue with **isObjectEqual** causes issues with other functions that use it.

For example, **isSameRoute(a, b)** (from *vue-router/src/util/route.js*) can return true for routes with different query objects (if query objects meet conditions listed above).  

I ran into this bug because sometimes programmatic navigation worked in unexpected ways when using **router.push** with a query object.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values" (#2233)

Issues.Title: Syntactic sugar for commiting mutations
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Committing mutations has a very strange syntax, which really stands out negatively, compared to the otherwise very elegant APIs found in the Vue/Vuex ecosystem:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

The docs mention that this is to emphasize that a commit is not a direct call to the mutation. I don't think this line of reasoning holds in the Vue/Vuex world. In almost all other aspects of Vue/Vuex, the API looks straight forward (e.g. just getting and setting properties), but under the hood a lot of additional logic runs (dependency tracking, etc.). So there is really no need to make committing mutations more cumbersome than they need to be.

In addition to making the code harder to read, this leads to additional rules about argument passing.

Moreover, it is very hard to spot typos in the mutation name early on, as the mutation name is just a string - let alone checking that the call to `commit()` received the correct arguments according to the mutation function. These types of errors should be easy to spot at compile time, but with the current syntax, these are all pushed into runtime.

Finally, this cumbersome syntax might be (correctly) perceived as boilerplate, especially to beginners. Hence, replacing the commit syntax with a more straight forward syntax might improve the adoption of Vuex.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Instead of:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

one should be allowed to write:

    this.$store.someMutation(args...)

Moreover, it would be great if looking at `this.$store` in the developer console all available mutation methods are shown. That is, the methods should be real properties of this.$store, collected once at program start.

Under the hood, of course, these methods might all call some central commit() function.

Alternative syntax: The above syntax might introduce some name collisions. For example, someone might name one of their mutations "state", for whatever reason, making "this.$store.state" ambiguous. For the sake of simplicity, these names should just be forbidden as mutation names. But if this is not an option for whatever reason, an intermediate object might do the trick as well. This would be less beautiful, but still better than what we have today:

    this.$store.commit.someMutation(args...)

or shorter:

    this.$store.c.someMutation(args...)

As an additional proposal, the old `this.$store.commit()` syntax should be marked deprecated.  And removed in future Vuex versions. This generic call is not needed. Any generic commit call might as well be formulated as `this.$store[mutationName](args...)`, which is still easy to understand and even shorter than `this.$store.commit(mutationName, args...)`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Many Google links returning 404s after conversion
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://vuex.vuejs.org/modules.html](https://vuex.vuejs.org/modules.html)

### Steps to reproduce
Try to visit any of the old URLs, or search Google for vuex topics and try to click through to the guide.  You will get 404s.

### What is expected?
301 redirects are in place so that users attempting to get help get to the right place.

### What is actually happening?
After the conversion to Vuepress it looks like the URL format changed from `vuex.vuejs.org/**.html` to `vuex.vuejs.org/guide/**.html`.  Google has not updated their listings, and many Stackoverflow posts will never update theirs.  As is, many users trying to get help will get frustrated and may give up altogether.

Issues.Title: The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports.
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/ciddan/vuex-ts-issue](https://github.com/ciddan/vuex-ts-issue)

### Steps to reproduce
Reproduction of an issue with the TypeScript type definitions in Vuex.

1. Clone the provided repository.
2. run npm install
3. run npm start
4. Open browser and go to http://localhost:8080.
5. Open dev tools and look at the console output.


### What is expected?
That the first log output: ```mapActions from: import { mapActions } undefined``` isn't undefined.

### What is actually happening?
mapActions is undefined.

---
Please read the README in the linked repository for full information on the issue.

We ran into this issue while working on TypeScript decorators that required the use of the various map functions.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports." (#1274)

Issues.Title: The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports
Issues.Body:
This is incorrect:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/types/index.d.ts#L6

Looking at vuex.js and vuex.common.js all of these functions are exported in the default export, not as named exports. This breaks our TypeScript/SystemJS project - since the TypeScript type of the default export only contains Store and install. Importing the map functions as named exports, i.e:
``` typescript
import { mapActions } from "vuex";
```
doesn't work either - since they're undefined at run time (SystemJS handles default and named exports differently). 

With "system" as the module format defined in tsconfig.json usage of a a named export is compiled to:
``` javascript
vuex_1.mapActions
```
Whereas usage of a default export is compiled to:
``` javascript
vuex_1.default.Store
```

The map functions should be exported together with Store and install here:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/types/index.d.ts#L129-L132

For reference, this is the export from vuex.js:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/dist/vuex.js#L925-L936
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports" (#1273)
